channel.title: Pressure Cooking on Cooking
channel.description: Recent content in Pressure Cooking on Cooking

item.title: Broccoli, Cauliflower, Carrots
item.description: Broccoli, Cauliflower, Carrots for Zero Minutes Came out tender, but not mushy. 1 cup of water and set it to zero minutes. Zero minutes does sound a little low, but it works :) Quick release immediately after the alarm sounds to let me know that zero minutes was reached. Waiting even one minute makes the vegtables soft. * Photo

item.title: Fresh Chicken
item.description: Fresh Chicken 1 cup of water with a chicken stock packet (from Trade Joes) and set it to 4 minutes on high. Do a natural release for 8 minutes. It came out tender with internal temps ranging from the 180s to 190s.

item.title: Frozen Chicken
item.description: Frozen Chicken 1 cup of water and set it to 10 minutes. Also added a packet of Trade Joes chicken stock. I was supposed to do a natural release, but I did a quick release and it didn’t seem to affect the texture. It came out tender, but I still plan to play with the times a bit in the future. Primarily because recommendations online that I read were all over the place.

item.title: Frozen Ground Beef
item.description: Frozen Ground Beef Came out tender. 1 cup of water and set it to 25 minutes with a quick release. Also added onions, garlic, and taco seasoning. Would alter this to 1⁄2 cup of water, plus add the onions, garlic, and seasoning after the initial pressure cooking.

item.title: Garlic Cauliflower Mash
item.description: Garlic Cauliflower Mash Bag of cauliflower florets from Costco. 2.5 TBSPs of butter. 6 cloves of garlic (I’d use 4 next time at the max). Salt, Pepper, and Paprika. 1/4th cup 2% milk (would be richer with half and half or whole milk). Cooked the cauliflower on high for 5 minutes with a quick release. During that I saut√©ed the garlic. Then after the cauliflower is done, dump it all into a blender and blend.
